dc:description: OMIM: Lujan-Fryns Syndrome (MIM:309520) Ohdo Syndrome, X-Linked (MIM:300895) Opitz-Kaveggia Syndrome (MIM:305450) Orphanet: Blepharophimosis-Intellectual Disability Syndrome, MKB Type (ORPHA:293707) FG Syndrome Type 1 (ORPHA:93932) X-Linked Intellectual Disability with marfanoid habitus (ORPHA:776) X-linked non-syndromic intellectual disability (ORPHA:777). The MED12 gene is associated with several disease entities in which all phenotypes occur within the spectrum of X-Linked Syndromic Intellectual Disability (ID). This association was made using case-level data only. Fifteen unique variants segregating in males (14 missense, 1 in-frame indel) and 1 de novo nonsense variant in a female proband have been reported. Female carriers of the MED12 variants can show mild ID and/or facial dysmorphism. MED12 was first associated with this disease in humans in 2007 (Rising et. al). This gene-disease association is supported by functional assays and animal models. In summary, MED12 is definitively associated with X-Linked MED12-related Intellectual Disability Syndrome. This classification was approved by the Intellectual Disability/Autism Gene Curation Expert Panel using the ClinGen Clinical Validity Framework on 04/18/2018. Lumping and Splitting : Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found no difference in molecular mechanism or inheritance pattern underlying the disease entities: (1) Lujan-Fryns Syndrome (MIM:309520), (2) Ohdo Syndrome (MIM:300895), and (3) Opitz-Kaveggia (FG) Syndrome (MIM:305450). Therefore the entities (MIM:309520, MIM:300895, MIM:305450) have been lumped into one disease entity, X-Linked MED12-related Intellectual Disability Syndrome.
curationReasonDescription: True total score is 14.5 with additional LOD scoring counted by original curator 3(8.74*).

evidence.dc:description: Downgraded since ID is hard to ascertain but assume brain function is related.
Embryo brain phenotype similar to WT.
evidence.rdfs:label: kto rescue

evidence.dc:description: De-repression of REST target genes was reversed back to wild-type levels.
evidence.rdfs:label: MED12 knockdown

evidence.dc:description: Quantitative RT-PCR on total mRNA extract clearly showed that JUN, FOS and EGR1 expression is down regulated in MED12-KD cells as confirmed by the decrease of their protein synthesis.
evidence.rdfs:label: CRISPR/Cas9 MED12-KD

evidence.dc:description: MED12 is a direct and functionally important transducer of canonical Wnt/b-catenin signaling. CTNNB1 is associated with mental retardation (MIM:615075) with patients showing other syndromic phenotypes, overlapping those with MED12 variants, including hypotonia, strabismus and speech impairment.
evidence.rdfs:label: Physical interaction with CTNNB1

evidence.dc:description: Female patient with severe phenotype including additional features not reported in males.

evidence.rdfs:label: DECIPHER_ID_263271
evidence.detectionMethod:
We sequenced the exomes of 1,133 children with developmental disorders
and their parents, from 1,101 families, representing 1,071 unrelated
children and 30 sibships. We also performed exome-focused array
comparative genomic hybridization (exome-aCGH) on the children
(n 5 1,009) and UK controls (n 5 1,013), and genome-wide genotyping
on the trios (n 5 1,006) to identify deletions, duplications, uniparental
disomy and mosaic large chromosome rearrangements.

evidence.dc:description: Expression studies showed that the mutated allele was not degraded by the non-sense- mediated RNA decay in EBV-immortalized lymphoblastoid cells and that it can produce an additional abnormal isoform due to the activation of two cryptic splice-sites within exon 41, and leading to a 75-bp deletion.

evidence.rdfs:label: III-14
evidence.detectionMethod: This family was then included in a large next generation sequencing project of the EUROMRX consortium aimed at identifying the pathogenic mutations in families with XLID. Genomic DNA (3 mg) from the affected male III-14 was used for constructing a single-end Illumina sequencing library using the Illumina Genomic DNA Single End Sample Prep kit, according to the instructions of the manufacturer. For X-chromosome exome enrichment we used the Agilent SureSelect Human X Chromosome Kit, which contains 47,657 RNA baits for 7,591 exons of the human X chromosome. Single end deep sequencing was performed on the Illumina Genome Analyzer GAIIx (read-length 76 nt). Sequencing covered 84% of the exonic region of the 1,024 genes targeted. Sequences were mapped using RazerS ( 5 mismatches) and SplazerS. Variant calling was performed with SNPstore resulting in a total of 2,692 variants. All sequence variants were prioritized by scoring phylogenetic conservation and functional impact (SIFT, PolyPhen2).

evidence.dc:description: Not scored as non-syndromic ID not commonly seen in MED12 patients. Only 86 genes sequenced. No segregation. Not seen in other patients. No experimental evidence.

evidence.rdfs:label: MPI-10
evidence.detectionMethod: Combined a novel droplet-based multiplex PCR method and next generation sequencing to screen patients with X-linked mental retardation (XLMR) for mutations in 86 previously identified XLMR genes

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 1
evidence.detectionMethod: Unknown - "Participant clinical histories and molecular test results were reviewed to confirm their diagnosis"

evidence.rdfs:label: III–2
evidence.detectionMethod: Whole exome sequencing analysis was performed in patient III–2 at the Radboud University Medical Center in Nijmegen, the Netherlands. Exome capture was performed with the Agilent SureSelect Human All Exon v4 enrichment kit (Agilent Technologies). Whole-exome sequencing was performed on the IlluminaHiSeq platform (BGI, Copenhagen, Denmark). Data were analyzed with BWA (read alignment,) and GATK (variant calling) software packages. Variants were annotated using an in-house developed pipeline. Prioritization of variants was done by an in-house designed “variant interface” and manual curation.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Array CGH-analysis (CytoChip ISCA 4 180 K v1.0 BlueGnome, Cambridge, UK) and Fragile-X genetic tests were performed on both living patients.

evidence.rdfs:label: III:1
evidence.detectionMethod: Whole-exome sequencing was performed for the proband, unaffected brother and parents, and subsequently also for the affected fetus as part of Baylor-Hopkins Center for Mendelian Genomics (BHCMG) project.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: In the proband, no copy number variants were detected on chromosomal microarray. Results of several single-gene tests per- formed in a diagnostic laboratory prior to WES, including sequencing and MLPA for CHD7, were normal.

evidence.rdfs:label: II-1
evidence.detectionMethod: Exome enrichment was performed with the SureSelect Human All Exon 50 Mb Kit (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA). Sequencing was performed on the SOLiD 5500xl sequencer (Life Technologies, Carlsbad, CA, USA). Reads were aligned to the UCSC Genome Browser hg19 reference genome with the use of Life Technologies LifeScope software version 2.1. Ninety two percent of the X chromosomal exons were covered at least three times on average in both individuals. Variants were annotated with a custom pipeline. Only nonsynonymous changes in the coding regions or changes affecting the canonical splice sites were analyzed. Variants present in dbSNP132 or in our in-house database containing data of 368 exomes were excluded. Assuming a hemizygous X chromosomal change, we only considered variants that were present in at least 70% of the reads on the X chromosome.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: 250k NspI SNP array analysis (Affymetrix, Santa Clara, CA, USA) revealed no significant chromosome aberrations.

evidence.dc:description: Supporting segregation data but downgraded due to no functional evidence.

evidence.rdfs:label: C1
evidence.detectionMethod: Based on the findings, the diagnosis of Opitz – Kaveggia syndrome was considered and we performed sequencing of exon 21 of the MED12 gene.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: An ophthalmological and neurological evaluation, echocardiogram, and metabolic screen in blood and urine were all normal. He had a normal male karyotype (46,XY). A deletion 22q11 was excluded using fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH). Analysis of the FMR1 and PTPN11 genes involved in Fragile-X (MIM #309550) and Noonan syndrome (MIM #163950), respectively, revealed no mutations.

evidence.rdfs:label: CMS0516
evidence.detectionMethod: To examine a possible role for MED12 in XLMR, we sequenced the 45 exons of MED12 in 24 index cases from XLMR families with linkage to Xq13. Sixteen of these families had lod scores >2, and the remainder were localized by concordance mapping. The latter group consisted of families with two to three affected males, and the localizations, although relatively broad, did not include more than one region.

evidence.rdfs:label: K8935
evidence.detectionMethod: Sequenced for all coding exons in MED12 as part of a general screen of a cohort of males with ID.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 1
evidence.detectionMethod: A custom SureSelect oligonucleotide probe library was designed to capture 19,878 coding exons of 614 pathogenic and 642 candidate genes associated with intellectual disability. A total of 71,994 probes, covering 5.073 Mbp (99.48% coverage of targets), were synthesized by Agilent Technologies (Santa Clara, CA). Sequence capture, enrichment, and elution were performed according to the manufacturer’s instructions.  e libraries were sequenced on an Illumina HiSeq 2000 platform with a paired-end run of 2 × 90 bp, following the manufacturer’s protocol to generate at least a 100× elective mean depth. Relevant variants were resequenced by Sanger sequencing. A er PCR amplication from DNA of the patient and his/her parents using specic primers, bidirectional sequencing was performed.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: All patients had a normal karyotype and were negative for fragile-X mutation. Whole genome dosage analysis was performed by 44K oligonucleotide array CGH (G4426B Agilent Technologies, Palo Alto, CA). No pathogenic variants were detected.

evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA was extracted from blood samples of the patients and parents when available. Exons and exon–intron boundaries sequencing analyses of the MED12 , ZDHHC9 , UPF3B , FBN1 , TGFBR1 and TGFBR2 genes were performed
evidence.previousTestingDescription: For etiological purposes, all patients were screened for mutations of the ZDHHC9 , UPF3B , MED12 , TGFBR1 , TGFBR2 , and FBN1 genes and for chromosomal micro-rearrangements using 244 K custom microarray. Female patients were also screened for X- inactivation bias.

evidence.rdfs:label: 7-year-old male
evidence.detectionMethod: Molecular testing of the MED12 gene was performed.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Extensive biochemical, cytogenetic, and molecular testing was performed based on discussion of other potential diagnoses and recommendations by one or more participating clinical geneticists. Molecular testing of the MED12 gene was performed on all individuals without a confirmed alternative diagnosis.

evidence.rdfs:label: II-5
evidence.detectionMethod: Systematic mutational screen of the X chromosome is currently directed at the coding exons and splice junctions of 737 Vega annotated genes that are being examined for variants by bidirectional, PCR-based direct sequencing.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: At least one individual from each of the 250 families was negative for an expansion of the trinucleotide repeat in the FMR1 gene underlying fragile X syndrome. A screen of 60 other known syndromic and nonsyndromic XLMR genes was conducted by sequencing of the coding exons and splice junctions, and the 250 families are also negative for mutations in these. All families have been examined and are free of abnormalities revealed by conventional karyotype analysis at 500 G-banding resolution.

evidence.rdfs:label: IV-2
evidence.detectionMethod:
Systematic mutational screen of the X chromosome
is currently directed at the coding exons and splice junctions
of 737 Vega annotated genes that are being examined
for variants by bidirectional, PCR-based direct sequencing.
evidence.previousTestingDescription:
At least one individual from each of the 250 families was
negative for an expansion of the trinucleotide repeat in
the FMR1 gene underlying fragile X syndrome. A screen
of 60 other known syndromic and nonsyndromic XLMR
genes was conducted by sequencing of the coding exons
and splice junctions, and the 250 families are also negative
for mutations in these. All families have been examined
and are free of abnormalities revealed by conventional
karyotype analysis at 500 G-banding resolution.

evidence.rdfs:label: CMS6656
evidence.detectionMethod: Following identification of the p.Arg961Trp variant, further analysis using a cohort of 41 individuals (comprising 29 unrelated male probands clinically diagnosed with Opitz-Kaveggia and 12 females with affected sons with the same diagnosis that are enrolled in XLMR research at the Greenwood Genetic Center) identified the same 2881C4T substitution in one additional affected male and two mothers of affected sons (both deceased).

evidence.dc:description: Not counted as phenotype ambiguous and parents consanguineous.

evidence.rdfs:label: K9338
evidence.detectionMethod: Sequencing of 718 genes on the X chromosome

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 1 (IV-2)
evidence.detectionMethod: Individuals with a clinical diagnosis of FG syndrome have been reexamined and tested for the p.R961W MED12 mutation.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: The results of chromosome analysis were normal.

evidence.dc:description: Not scoring as phenotype is ambiguous.

evidence.rdfs:label: S_067
evidence.detectionMethod: Enrichment for exome sequencing was performed using the SureSelect Human All Exon V5 kit (50 Mb, ~ 21,000 genes) (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, USA). Resulting libraries were sequenced on an Illumina Hiseq 2500 system (Illumina, Inc., San Diego, USA) to produce 125 bp paired-end reads. The annotated variants were filtered using manually curated lists of 923 currently known ID genes and 543 published ID candidate genes retrieved from the SysID database (http:// sysid.cmbi.umcn.nl/)
evidence.previousTestingDescription: In-house diagnostic chromosomal microarray testing, either with an Affymetrix 6.0 Mapping Array or an Affymetrix CytoScan HD-Array (Affymetrix, Santa Clara, CA, USA), had been performed without obviously pathogenic aberrations in 92 individuals and normal testing for Fragile- X syndrome in 35 of the males and 32 of the females.

evidence.rdfs:label: III-10
evidence.detectionMethod: We obtained blood samples from the only surviving affected male from the original Opitz-Kaveggia family (K9346) and his mother to further study the connection with MED12. The affected male was hemizygous and his mother heterozygous for the 2881C>T change.

evidence.rdfs:label: CMS0125
evidence.detectionMethod: To examine a possible role for MED12 in XLMR, we sequenced the 45 exons of MED12 in 24 index cases from XLMR families with linkage to Xq13. Sixteen of these families had lod scores >2, and the remainder were localized by concordance mapping. The latter group consisted of families with two to three affected males, and the localizations, although relatively broad, did not include more than one region.

evidence.dc:description: Did not score due to ambiguous phenotype

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 10
evidence.detectionMethod:
DNA samples from peripheral blood cells were prepared according to standard protocols. Fragmentation of patient DNA samples was carried out with a Covaris S2 ultrasonicator, generating fragments of 200–500 bp in size (Covaris, Woburn, MA, USA). For library generation of the fragmented samples, the Illumina Paired-End DNA Sample Preparation Kit was used (Illumina, San Diego, CA, USA).
Enrichment of the target sequences, which included nearly all coding and flanking intronic regions of the X-chromosome, was performed using the Agilent SureSelectXT X-Chromosome in-solution target enrichment kit (Agilent, Santa Clara, CA, USA) followed by individual barcoding of each sample.
Sequencing was performed using the Illumina GAIIx sequencer (2 × 76 paired-end sequencing). Analysis of variants was restricted to the coding and flanking intronic sequences of 107 XLID genes.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Chromosome aberrations were ruled out by microarray analysis (array CGH or SNP array) in all patients before they were included into this study. Fragile X syndrome was excluded in all patients by testing for CGG repeat expansions in the 5′ untranslated region of FMR1. Patients with a history of seizures were also tested for the recurrent 24 bp duplication in exon 2 of ARX. All patients were seen by a clinical geneticist to rule out obvious syndromic disorders.

evidence.dc:description: Not scored as phenotype not convincingly typical of MED12 patients.

evidence.rdfs:label: 12-year-old boy
evidence.detectionMethod: Subsequently, targeted resequencing was performed using TruSight One v1.0 sequencing panel (Illumina, San Diego, CA, USA), which includes 125,396 probes aimed to capture 11,946,514-bp targeted exon regions consisting of 4,813 genes that are associated with known clinical phenotypes. After constructing the sequence library using 50 ng of genomic DNA, the MiSeq next-generation sequencer (Illumina) was used to sequence 151-bp paired-end reads according to the manufacturer’s instructions. The extracted data were mapped to a reference genome (GRCh37/hg19) using BWA Enrichment v1.0 cloud software (Illumina).
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Genomic copy number aberrations were examined using an Agilent SurePrint G3 Human CGH Microarray Kit 8 × 60 K (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA) which demonstrated no aberrations.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient
evidence.detectionMethod: His whole exome sequencing (outsourced to Medgenome Labs Pvt. Ltd.).  His mother was found to be a heterozygous carrier of the same mutation. She had normal stature and intellect.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Investigations including karyotype, FMR1 repeats, MRI brain, cytogenetic microarray, hearing, and echocardiography were normal.

evidence.rdfs:label: II-10
evidence.detectionMethod: Individuals with a clinical diagnosis of FG syndrome have been reexamined and tested for the p.R961W MED12 mutation.

evidence.rdfs:label: III-1
evidence.detectionMethod:
DNA was isolated from a transformed lymphoblastoid cell line of the nephew because both he and his uncle were deceased. Exome enrichment was performed
with the SureSelect Human All Exon 50 Mb Kit (Agilent
Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA). Sequencing was performed
on the SOLiD 5500xl sequencer (Life Technologies,
Carlsbad, CA, USA). Reads were aligned to the UCSC
Genome Browser hg19 reference genome with the use of
Life Technologies LifeScope software version 2.1. Ninety two
percent of the X chromosomal exons were covered
at least three times on average in both individuals. Variants
were annotated with a custom pipeline. Only nonsynonymous
changes in the coding regions or changes affecting
the canonical splice sites were analyzed. Variants present
in dbSNP132 or in our in-house database containing data
of 368 exomes were excluded. Assuming a hemizygous X
chromosomal change, we only considered variants that
were present in at least 70% of the reads on the X chromosome.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: 250k NspI SNP array analysis (Affymetrix, Santa Clara, CA, USA) revealed no significant chromosome aberrations.

evidence.rdfs:label: II-1
evidence.detectionMethod:
We performed Sanger sequencing of all
45 coding exons of MED12 on DNA from nine simplex
male persons with the clinical diagnosis of Ohdo syndrome.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 7
evidence.detectionMethod:
For 7 samples exome sequencing was done at the Genomics Core Facility, KU Leuven,
Leuven, Belgium. Exome capture was performed with the SeqCap EZ Human Exome
Library v3.0 (NimbleGen). Another 12 patients were whole exome sequenced at Baylor College of Medicine. Variant confirmation was done by PCR and Sanger
sequencing in the patients and their parents if DNA was available. X-linked variants that
were paternally inherited were excluded from further analysis. Autosomal variants that were
inherited from either parent were also excluded if no other potentially damaging variants
were detected in that gene. Escape of X-inactivation was evaluated based on the study of
Carrel and Willard.

evidence.rdfs:label: K9467
evidence.detectionMethod: Sequenced for all coding exons of MED12.

evidence.rdfs:label: III.2
evidence.detectionMethod: X-linked Intellectual Disability Panel was sent to Greenwood Genetics.

evidence.rdfs:label: III-1
evidence.detectionMethod: Individuals with a clinical diagnosis of FG syndrome have been reexamined and tested for the p.R961W MED12 mutation.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 1
evidence.detectionMethod: DNA capture was achieved with Illumina’s Nextera Rapid Capture Exome Kit. NextSEq 500 Sequencer (Illumina, Inc., San Diego, California, United States) along with the NextSEq 500 High Output Kit was used for massive parallel sequencing. bcl2fastq software 2.17.1.14 (Illumina, Inc.) was used to convert raw sequencing reads to standard FASTQ format. Reads were mapped to human reference genome (GRCh37/ hg19) by BWA software. Variant calling was done by GATK HaplotypeCaller, FreeBayes, and SAM- tools. Annotation of variants was done by using ANNOVAR.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Karyotype at resolution of 500 to 550 bands is normal (46,XY) for both siblings. Thyroid function test were normal for both patients.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 2
evidence.detectionMethod: Unknown - "Participant clinical histories and molecular test results were reviewed to confirm their diagnosis"
